remarks: While Diophantine sets were defined to have a finite number of witness variables consequtively following the observable variables, this is not necessary; they can equivalently be taken to use any witness set ` ( S \ ( 1 ... N ) ) ` .  For instance, in ~ diophin we use this to take the two input sets to have disjoint witness sets.  (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 8-Oct-2014.)

eldioph2b $p |- ( ( ( N e. NN0 /\ S e. _V ) /\ ( -. S e. Fin /\ ( 1 ... N ) C_ S ) ) -> ( A e. ( Dioph ` N ) <-> E. p e. ( mzPoly ` S ) A = { t | E. u e. ( NN0 ^m S ) ( t = ( u |` ( 1 ... N ) ) /\ ( p ` u ) = 0 ) } ) ) $.
$d A p $.
